conclusion: Analyze the motion of the blocks on the curved track and inclined plane, apply conservation principles, and determine heat generated during collision.

Curved track connects to horizontal ground at point O. Block A with mass m starts at height h and slides down to collide with stationary block B with mass 2m at O. They move onto inclined plane C with mass 3m, rising to a height less than the inclined plane.
Block A has mass m and starts at height h. Block B has mass 2m and is stationary at point O. Inclined plane has mass 3m.
Potential energy of block A at height h is converted into kinetic energy at point O.
At point O, total energy is shared between blocks A and B.
After collision, blocks A and B stick together with combined mass of 3m. Collision is inelastic, converting some energy into heat.
Before collision, total momentum is zero since both blocks are at rest. After collision, combined mass 3m moves with velocity v.
Kinetic energy at point O is equal to potential energy at height h. This energy is conserved as combined mass moves up inclined plane.
Inelastic collision converts some initial potential energy into heat. Heat generated is difference between initial potential energy and final kinetic energy.
Initial potential energy is mgh. Final kinetic energy is (1/2) * 3m * v^2. Heat generated is mgh - (1/2) * 3m * v^2.
Since energy is conserved, (1/2) * 3m * v^2 = mgh. Solving for v, find v = sqrt(2gh/3).
Substitute v into heat equation: mgh - (1/2) * 3m * (sqrt(2gh/3))^2. Simplify to find heat generated.
Heat generated during collision of A and B is (1/6)mgh.
